File.Title: Are There Connections Between the Thalamic Reticular Nucleus and the Brainstem Reticular Formation?
File.Authors: D.J. BERRY, P.T. OHARA, G. JEFFERY, AND A.R. LIEBERMAN

Abstract.S: Increasing awareness that the thalamic reticular nucleus (TRN) plays an important role in controlling the output of cortically projecting cells in nuclei of the dorsal thalamus has focused attention on the question of whether there exist ascending projections to the TRN from the mesencephalic or other parts of the brainstem reticular formation (BRF).

We have examined this and the related question of whether the neurons of TRN project to the BRF, by anterograde and retrograde tracing experiments with horseradish peroxidase (HRP) and HRP conjugated to wheat germ agglutinin.

Injections of tracer were placed stereotaxically in the BRF at various depths and rostrocaudal and mediolateral coordinates, and the TRN and adjacent nuclei were examined in serial coronal sections, using tetramethylbenzidine as the principal chromogen.
Retrogradely labelled cell bodies were consistently seen in hypothalamus and zona incerta but never in TRN, suggesting that, in the rat, TRN neurons do not project caudal to the thalamus.

After 54 out of 60 injections, no terminal label was detected in any part of the TRN although such label was present in other parts of the thalamus, including the intralaminar nuclei, in the same sections.

We therefore conclude that direct projections from the BRF to the TRN must be extremely sparse, and that those effects of BRF stimulation upon thalamocortical transmission that are mediated by the TRN (rather than by direct projections to dorsal thalamic nuclei) probably depend chiefly on indirect polysynaptic pathways.

Introduction.S: It has long been believed that the brainstem reticular formation (BRF) is involved in determining states of consciousness.

Moruzzi and Magoun ( 49) stimulated the BRF of encephale isole cats and found that this evoked a change in the electroencephalogram (EEG) from a pattern of highvoltage slow waves to one of low-voltage fast waves.
This desynchronization of the EEG was found to duplicate the change in the EEG obtained on arousal (for reviews and references see Rossi and Zanchetti, 57; Singer, 77).
Directly related to cortical desynchronization is facilitation of transmission through the thalamic relay nuclei (see, for example, Steriade, 70; Singer, 77).
The subset of neurons that brings about these effects on the EEG afbr stimulation of the BRF has been termed the ascending activating system.

It has long been thought that the thalamic reticular nucleus (TRN) has an important role in this system, and for many years it was believed that the TRN represented the final common pathway of the ascending system from the BRF to the cerebral cortex (Jasper, 49).
Now, however, it is known that the TRN projects to the dorsal thalamus and that there is no direct projection from the TRN to cerebral cortex (Minderhoud, 71; Jones, 75).

Nevertheless, a role for the TRN in determining the pattern and extent of cortical activity remains very probable, for it has been shown in a number of studies that projections from the TRN to the dorsal thalamus exert an inhibitory effect on thalamocortical projection cells (e.g., Schlag and Waszak, '71; Frigyesi and Schwartz, '72; Waszak, '74; French et al., '841 and thus, indirectly, on the activity of cortical neurons.
The last few years have also seen the accumulation of much additional information about the organization of the TRN.

Evidence for the inhibitory effect of neurons in the TRN on thalamocortical projection cells has been supported by anatomical evidence that the axons of these cells (reticulothalamic axons) terminate by establishing Gray type 2 (symmetrical) synapses with the dendrites of thalamocortical projection cells (Ohara et al., '80; Montero and Scott, '81; Peschanski et al., '83) and by immunohistochemicaI evidence that the transmitter at these endings is GABA mouser et al., '80; Ohara et al., '83).

It is also now established from both physiological and anatomical studies that reticulothalamic neurons are monosynaptically excited by thalamic and cortical inputs, both almost certainly in the form of collaterals of thalamocortical and corticothalamic projection cells (Schlag and Waszak, '71; Ohara and Lieberman, '81, '85).

In addition, it is also now apparent that the reticulothalamic projections may be more highly organized than would appear to be the case from the studies of Scheibel and Scheibel('66) and Jones ('75).

Thus small injections of horseradish peroxidase (HRP) or fluorescent tracers into the dorsal thalamus label only small patches of adjacent neurons in the ipsilateral TRN (O'Connell et al., '82, rat; Frassoni et al., '84, rat; Steriade et al., '84, cat), suggesting that such cells project discretely to the small regions of dorsal thalamus from which they receive input.

In the light of findings such as these, and of evidence that the activity of TRN neurons is closely linked to the firing pattern of thalamocortical projection cells, it can now be accepted as established that although the circuitry may be very different from that originally envisaged, the TRN does indeed influence cortical physiology, functioning as part of a feedback circuit by which thalamocortical cell activity is regulated.
But there remains the question of the precise nature of the relationship between the TRN and the BRF.

There is some anatomical evidence for projections from the BRF to the TRN (e.g., Scheibel and Scheibel, '58; Shute and Lewis, '67; Edwards and De Olmos, '76; Kromer and Moore, '80; Robertson and Feiner, '82; Mackay-Sim et al., '83; Cropper et al, '84; Peschanski and Besson, '841, but the evidence is sparse and not entirely satisfactory (see Discussion).
The physiological evidence is more extensive and supports more strongly than the anatomical evidence the existence of projections, but it is no less difficult to interpret.

There are several studies that strongly suggest that in the cat there is a direct input to the TRN from the mesencephalic reticular formation (MRF) that is both inhibitory and cholinergic (Ben-hi et al., '76; Dingeldine and Kelly, '77; Godfraind and Veraart, '781, and evidence such as this leads to the conclusion that the facilitation of thalamocortical transmission underlying cortical arousal following BRF stimulation depends upon a disinhibition of the thalamocortical projection cells brought about by ascending input from the BRF to the TRN that reduces the inhibitory output of the latter (Singer, '77).

Plausible though this suggestion may be (Fig. lA), there are other data that suggest that the facilitatory effects of BRF stimulation may be mediated by direct excitatory inputs to thalamocortical projection cells (Kayama et al., '82) (Fig. lB), or by disinhibition involving intrathalamic inhibitory interneurons (e.g., Fukuda and Iwama, '71) (Fig. 1C).

Furthermore, the anatomical evidence fur direct projections from the BRF to the specific nuclei of the dorsal thalamus is more extensive and less open to doubts than is the evidence for direct projections to the TRN (e.g., Kromer and Moore, '80; Pasquier and Villar, '82; Ahlsen and Lo, '82; Hughes and Mullikin, '84, Sofroniew et al., '85).

The present study, undertaken against this confused and uncertain background, is an attempt to establish if projections from the BRF to the TRN are present in the rat, and if so to determine their origins more precisely.
A second question we were interested in clarifying is that of whether there are projections from TRN that descend caudal to the diencephalon.

Axons extending from the TRN to the midbrain are described by Scheibel and Scheibel('66) in Golgi material from various species, by Grofova et al. ('78) on the basis of retrograde HRP labelling studies in the cat, and by Parent and Steriade ('84) on the basis of electrophysiological and retrograde labelling studies in cat and squirrel monkey.

On the other hand, Minderhoud ('71), in experimental degeneration studies in the rat, Jones ('79, in autoradiographic studies in various species after injection of labelled amino acids into the TRN, and others in retrograde HRP labelling studies (Morel1 et al., '81; Shammah-Lagnado et al., '83; Frassoni et al., '84) found no such projections.
We have employed anterograde and retrograde tracing methods, using both HRP and HRP conjugated to wheat germ agglutinin, to examine these questions in adult albino rats.
A preliminary report of the findings has been published (Berry et al., '83).

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
Animals
Albino rats of the Wistar strain, 170-200 g in weight, were used.
In thirty-five of these animals injections of HRP or of HRP conjugated with wheat germ agglutinin (WGAHRP) were made into various parts of the BRF.
Five animals were used to prepare reference series of coronal sections stained to show the presence of acetylcholinesterase (AChE).
Injection procedures
The rats were lightly anaesthetized with ether and placed in a David Kopf small-animal stereotaxic frame.

Deep anaesthesia was then induced and maintained with either a mixture of halothane, nitrous oxide, and oxygen or an intraperitoneal injection of Chlor-Nembutal (3.0 ml/kg of 2.1 g chloral hydrate and 0.5 g sodium pentabarbital in 50 ml of water) or of chloral hydrate alone.
A total of 60 injections (ten unilateral or midline and 50 bilateral) were made into the brainstem of the thirty-five animals.
Forty-one injections were with HRP and 19 with WGA-HRP.

In 33 injections HRP (Sigma type VI) was used as a 15% solution in TRIS buffer and was injected by iontophoresis using stereotaxically positioned micropipettes with tip diameters of 50-70 pm and currents of 5-15 pA over periods of 2.5-5 minutes.
Eight injections of HRP (0.1 pl of 30% HRP in normal saline) were made by using a pressure system and a stereotaxically positioned 1-pl Hamilton microsyringe with an outside diameter of 1 mm.
Nine of the WGA-HRP injections were made iontophoretically by using a 3% sohA
tion of WGA-HRP in TRIS buffer, stereotaxically positioned micropipettes with tip diameters of 50-70 pm, and currents of 5-15 pA for 2.5-5 minutes.
The other ten injections were of 10% (six injections) and 4% (four injections) WGA-HRP in TRIS buffer with a pressure ejection system.
Preparation of tissue

Twenty-four to 48 hours after injection, animals were again deeply anaesthetized (with ether) and killed by transcardiac perfusion of 50 ml of 0.1 M phosphate buffer followed by 200 ml of a solution of 1% glutaraldehyde and 1% paraformaldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.3; room temperature).
The brains were removed and stored in fresh fixative solution for 5-12 hours at 4°C.
Brains to be cut on the freezing microtome were stored in 0.1 M phosphate buffer containing 20% sucrose overnight at 4°C prior to sectioning.
Serial coronal sections 50 pm thick were cut on a freezing microtome with solid carbon dioxide as a refrigerant or in a Vibratome (Oxford Instruments) and were collected in 0.1 M phosphate buffer.
Alternate sections were processed by using diaminobenzidine (DAB) or tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) as chromogens (LaVail and LaVail, '74; Mesulam, '78) and mounted on gelatinized slides.
Some sections treated with TMB were counterstained with neutral red and DAB sections were counterstained with cresyl violet.
In some experiments only TMB was used and alternate sections were counterstained with neutral red.
The slides were coverslipped and examined by light microscopy in both brightfield and darkfield illumination.
Sections treated with DAB and TMB were used to identify the injection sites and the extent of spread of the HRP.
Labelling of cell bodies, fibres, and terminals at levels rostral to the superior colliculus was assessed only in TMB sections.
The results were recorded on line drawings of frontal sections of the brain.
Special attention was paid to the area of, and adjacent to, the TRN, where labelling was recorded in detail with the aid of a camera lucida.
The atlases of Pellegrino et al. ('671, Konig and Klippel ('63), and Paxinos and Watson ('82) were used.
AChE staining
The animals were perfused as described above.
Serial coronal sections of the brains, 25 pm thick, were cut on a freezing microtome and stained for AChE according to Hanker et al. ('73).
Some sections were counterstained with cresyl violet.
The boundaries of the TRN were traced from these series of sections with a camera lucida.

Results.S: Injections were placed throughout the brainstem, from the medulla caudally to the midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus rostrally.

Although many injections were centred on nuclear groups which have been implicated as possible sources of ascending projections to the TRN (viz.locus coeruleus, raphe nuclei, nucleus cuneiformis, and other parts of the MRF) few parts of the BRF and MRF were not included within at least some injection sites.

The coordinates used for the injections are summarized in Table 1 and representative injection sites into the MRF at the level of the superior colliculus, into the periaqueductal gray PAG) at the level of the inferior colliculus, into the lateral BRF at the level of the facial nerve nucleus, and into the midline at the level of transition between pons and midbrain are shown in Figure 2.
Further details of the structures included within individual injection sites are given where appropriate in the text.
For convenience of description, the findings are presented in three groups according to the rostrocaudal level of the injections.
Injections into the MRF at the level of the superior colliculus

TTE.S: Thirteen injections-ten of HRP and three of WGA-HRP were placed in the MRF at the level of the superior colliculus.

Sections treated with DAB showed that the diffusion zone extended ventrally beyond the deepest layer of the superior colliculus (stratum album profundum) in all 13 injections, involved the MRF in eight injections and the PAG in three out of 13 injections (Figs. 2A, 3).
In TMB sections the diffusion zone included the MRF and adjacent PAG in every case.
One centrally placed injection included both rostral dorsal raphe and raphe medianus.
Figure 5 summarises the pattern of diencephalic labelling in one experiment following an injection very similar to the one depicted in Figure 3.
These findings and the findings from all other animals in this group are summarised in Table 1.
Labelling within the TRN.
No labelled cells were observed within the TRN after any injections.
Sparse fibre labelling within the TRN was seen after three injections of HRP in three different animals.

All of these injections were centred at approximately the midrostrocaudal level of the superior colliculus and in every case involved deep superior colliculus (to the level of the stratum album profundum) and the dorsal MRF.
In every case the labelled fibres ran diagonally and roughly horizontally from the ventrolateral part of the ventral thalamus, through the TRN, to enter the internal capsule laterally.

The fibres were sparse and confined to the ventral part of the caudal TRN (A/p t 3.9 to A/P +4.1), just dorsal to the junction of the latter with the zona incerta (ZI) as determined by comparison of TMB treated sections with AChE-stained sections cut at the same level (Fig. 4).
Sparse terminal labelling within TRN was seen after five injections-two of WGA-HRP and three of HRP alone.
The injection sites involved both dorsal and ventral levels in the MRF and included none of the injections after which sparse fibre labelling was seen in TRN.

The terminal label consisted of fine granules of reaction product over the neuropil and cell islands of the caudal half of the TRN (ALP +3.9 to A/P +4.6) in the interstices of the fibre bundles running between thalamus and internal capsule.

In all five 2 cases there was evidence of leakage of HRP into the cerebral cortex from the pipette track, and in four of the five cases there were labelled cell bodies in the ipsilateral dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus.
Labelling in other sites. (1) After almost every injection, cell, fibre, and terminal labelling was seen within the ZI (Table 1, Fig. 5).

Terminal labelling within the ZI, the lateral boundary of which was defined by the AChE technique (Fig. 41, was most obvious in the dorsal part of the nucleus, whereas labelled cell bodies were seen predominantly in the ventral half of the ZI.
Cell body labelling was granular in nature and extended into the dendrites to reveal that many of the labelled cells were bipolar with processes emerging at either end of an elongate soma (Fig. 6).
In most cases it was apparent that heavily labelled cells within the ZI were arranged as two bands parallel to one another and to the dorsal edge of the crus cerebri.
Labelled fibres were seen throughout the ZI running parallel with the cells in the ventral half and forming a plexus in the dorsal half.
This plexus consisted of fibres running horizontally, and perpendicular to the medial border of the medial lemniscus.
In the area H1 of Forel s field, the horizontally running fibres passed dorsally into the medial thalamus.
Labelling disappeared from the ZI approximately one-third of the distance along the caudorostral axis of the TRN.
(2) In all but two cases,terminal labelling was observed within the intralaminar nuclear complex (nucleus medialis thalami, pars lateralis of Konig and Klippel, 63) (Figs. 5, 7) (Table 1).
(3) In all but two cases, in one of which labelling was generally weak, labelled cell bodies were present within the hypothalamus (Figs. 5, 8) (Table 1).
Such cells were located in both the posterior and middle groups of hypothalamic nuclei as described by Christ ( 69).
(4) In most cases, labelled fibres could be seen running vertically and dorsomedially through the ventral lateral geniculate nucleus and dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus.
Labelled cells were seen in the ventral part of the ventral lateral geniculate nucleus in several cases.

Results.S: Injections into the PAG and caudal MRF

TTE.S: Eight injections of HRP and two of WGA-HRP were placed in the PAG at levels between the caudal superior colliculus and the inferior colliculus, and in all cases the diffusion zone around the site of the injection extended into the medial part of the adjacent MRF (Figs. 2B, 9).
Four injections of WGA-HRP were made into the lateral MRF, and one into the midline.
In the anteroposterior dimension the injections extended from the level of the caudal superior colliculus to the level of the caudal inferior colliculus (Table 1).

Four injections were made into the most caudal part of the PAG and into its caudal extension, the periventricular gray, at approximately the midlevel of the locus coerulus: two of HRP alone, two of WGA-HRP.
The diffusion zones of the midline injection (Fig. 2D) and of the two most medial and rostral injections into the pons involved the dorsal raphe nucleus and nucleus raphe medianus.
Diencephalic labelling following this group of injections is summarised in Table 1 and Figure 13 shows the labelling pattern on the left side in the case of the experiment illustrated in Figure 2D.
Labelling within the TRN.
No cell, fibre, or terminal labelling was observed within the TRN after any of these injections.

In Figure 10 the absence of label in the TRN may be contrasted with the adjacent terminal labe1 in the thalamic ventrobasal complex following the injection illustrated in Figure 2D, which involved a substantial caudorostral extent of the raphe nuclei (including raphe medianus) and adjacent parts of the MRF and BRF.
Labelling in other sites.

In nine cases labelled fibres were seen in the dorsal ZI (Table 1) passing rostromedially toward the medial thalamus through the fields of Forel, in which fibre labelling was seen after 11 injections.
Terminal labelling was seen in the intralaminar nuclei after 14 injections (Table 1, Figs. 11, 13) and sporadically in the ZI and lateral geniculate nuclei.
Cell labelling was found consistently in the dorsocaudal part of the ZI and to a lesser extent in the central part of the ZI along its entire rostrocaudal length (Table 1, Figs. 12,13).
Cell bodies were labelled in the hypothalamus after 17 of the 19 injections (Table 1).

Results.S: Injections into the pontomedullary reticular formation

TTE.S: Twenty-eight injections were made into the pontomedullary reticular formation, seven with WGA-HRP.

Injection sites (e.g., Fig. 2C) ranged from the midline to the lateral BRF and from the most rostral part of the facial nucleus to the inferior cerebellar peduncle, and were at a range of heights such that both ventral and dorsal BRF were included in the injections (Table 1).
One injection of WGAHRP was centered on the locus coeruleus and the diffusion zone of HRP in DAB-treated sections after two other injections included the locus coeruleus (Fig. 14).
Six midline injections involved the nucleus raphe magnus.

Seven injection tracks passed through the brachium conjuctivum, and the larger of these injections produced a diffusion zone that extended to the spinal tract of the trigeminal nerve in TMBtreated sections.
Six injections were made at the level of the inferior cerebellar peduncle.

The findings for this group of injections are summarized in Table 1 and Figure 16 shows the pattern of diencephalic labelling for an experiment in which the injection site (HRP alone) was in the pons caudal to the level of the inferior colliculi.
Labelling in TRN.
No labelling was seen within the TRN except for very sparse terminal labelling within the most rostral part of TRN after the WGA-HRP injection centred on the locus coeruleus.
Labelling in other sites.
Fibre labelling was seen in the ZI in 19 cases and in the HI area of the fields of Forel in nine cases (Table 1, Fig. 16).
Labelled fibres in the ZI passed medially and dorsally within the field of Forel H1 toward the medial part of the thalamus (Figs. 15, 16).

Sporadic fibre labelling was also seen in the lateral geniculate nuclei and hypothalamus, and in the case of three injections that involved the locus coeruleus sparse terminal label was seen within the dorsal and ventral lateral geniculate nuclei.
In 17 cases terminal labelling was also seen within the intralaminar nuclei (Fig. 16), in eight cases in the ZI, and in six cases in the hypothalamus.
Cell labelling was found in only two sites: the hypothalamus (ten cases) and the 21 (ten cases).

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
question of descending efferents from TRN
to the brainstem

Scheibel and Scheibel ( 66) reported that in their Golgi material (chiefly rodent brains) 20% of all axons of TRN neurons could be traced to the mesencephalic tegmentum, where they were lost among the cells of the MRF.

These findings are difficult to evaluate because Golgi material is not ideal for tracing axonal projections and because the Scheibels relied heavily on very young animals in which the spread of axonal arbors of TRN neurons may have been more extensive than in adult animals.
Nevertheless, support for such a projection has emerged from more recent experimental studies.

Thus Grofova et al. ( 78) have reported that labelled cells are consistently found in the TRN of cats, following injection of HRP into the deep layers of the superior colliculus, into the PAG, and into the MRF.

More recently, Parent and Steriade ( 84) have reported antidromic activation of cells in the TRN of cats following electrical stimulation of the MRF, and retrograde cell labelling in the rostra1 pole and lateral part of TRN in cats and squirrel monkeys, following injection of HRP or fluorescent tracers in the MRF, and in the posteroventral part of the TRN following injection into the superior colliculus.

These authors also present evidence, based on double labelling experiments with fluorescent dyes injected into both MRF and dorsal thalamus, that the axons projecting to the MRF do not arise, for the most part, from the same neurons that send axons to the dorsal thalamus.
However, other data in the recent literature raise doubts about the extent and ubiquity of axonal projections from the TRN to the MRF.

Thus in an earlier study Steriade et al. ( 82) also made HRP injections into the MRF of cats but found very few labelled cells in the TRN: they concluded that the projection described by Grofova et al. ( 78) must be directed chiefly to the PAG, which had not been included in their injections.

This conclusion, however, seems not to be entirely in keeping with the findings of Grofova et al. ( 781, who did indeed find labelled cells in the TRN after injections into the PAG, but concluded that the projections to the MRF were stronger.
Furthermore, Mantyh ( 82) found few if any labelled cells in the TRN of cat, rat, or monkey following small injections of HRP confined to the PAG.
In other recent HRP studies, no labelled cells were found in the TRN of rats after injections into a number of MRF sites (Morrell et al., 81; Shammah-Lagnado et al., 83; Frassoni et al., 84).

Finally, in other experimental studies, Minderhoud ( 71) found no retrograde changes in TRN neurons of rat following large lesions of the midbrain and no terminal degeneration in the latter after lesions of the TRN, while Jones ('75) found no sign of terminal label caudal to the thalamus following injections of labelled amino acids into the TRN in cat and monkey.

Thus a considerable body of previously published work, and our own findings, are difficult to reconcile with other evidence favouring the existence of a substantial descending projection from the TRN to the midbrain (or to more caudal levels of the brainstem).

Since most of the evidence in favour of the existence of such projections derives from studies on cats and monkeys (Grofova et al., '78; Parent and Steriade, '84) whereas many of the negative findings reported relate to work on rodents (Minderhoud, "71; Morel1 et al., '81; Shammah-Lagnado et al., '83; Frassoni et al., '84; present study), it would seem reasonable to suppose that there may be differences between species in the organization of efferents from the TRN.
The question of afferents to the TRN from the BRF
The evidence for projections from the BRF to the TRN is extensive and some of it reasonably strong.

One of the most widely cited studies is that of Edwards and De Olmos ('76), who reported terminal labelling in the TRN of the cat after injection of tritiated leucine into the nucleus cuneiformis, a nucleus of the MRF that has also been identified in the rat (Valverde, '621, and described as the "deep mesencephalic nucleus" by others (Veazey and Severin, '80).

The findings of Edwards and De Olmos ('76) have been influential because they fit very well with histochemical evidence for an AChE-rich projection arising from the nucleus cuneiformis and extending to or through the TRN (Shute and Lewis, '67; Hoover and Jacobowitz, '79), with immunohistochemical evidence for cholinergic cell bodies in the mesencephalic (and pontine) tegmentum (Armstrong et al., '83) and for projections from such cells to the thalamus (Sofroniew et al, '85).

These findings are also consonant with electrophysiological and pharmacological evidence for the existence of a cholinergic inhibitory input to the TRN from the midbrain in the cat (Ben-Ari et al., '76; Dingeldine and Kelly, "77).
There is also evidence for projections to the TRN from more caudal levels of the BRF.

Scheibel and Scheibel ('58), in one of the earliest studies providing anatomical evidencc for such projections, reported that axons of neurons in thc BRF at the level of the caudal pons, and in the rostra medulla (magnocellular medullary area), reached the TRN There is also evidence for a noradrenergic input to the TRN from the locus coeruleus: Kromer and Moore ('80) reported that ascending noradrenergic axons from the locus coeruleus in the rat displayed terminallike varicosities within the caudal TRN, adjacent to the lateral geniculate nucleus, and noradrenergic axons within the TRN have also been identified by Lindvall et al. ('74) and Swanson and Hartman ('75).
We found no terminal labelling in this part of the TRN and sparse terminal label was identified only in the rostra1 part of the TRN after an injection of WGA-HRP centred on the locus coeruleus.

No terminal or fibre labelling was seen in the TRN after any of the injections involving raph6 nuclei, although a serotonin input to the TRN from the raph6 nuclei has also been described (Chan-Palay, '77; Moore et al., '78; Cropper et al., '841, which, according to Bobillier et al. ('76), in the cat arises only in the nucleus raph6 pontis.
More recently Peschanski and Besson ('84) have demonstrated sparse anterograde labelling in the TRN following iontophoretic injections of 10% WGA-HRP into the nucleus raph6 medianus of the rat.

However, it is not clear from the data presented whether the label identified in the TRN was in fibres of passage or in terminals, and the possibility that the label may have been transneuronal will be considered below.

Finally, Robertson and Feiner ('82) reported sparse fibre and terminal labelling in the ventral TRN (extending into the ZI and fields of Forel) after injections of tritiated leucine into the pontine BRF in the cat.

All of the above findings have been made with anterograde labelling methods: there are also some important data based on retrograde labelling studies, the interpretation of which, however, is bedevilled by the shape and size of the TRN, which makes it difficult to be certain that injections centred on the TRN result in labelling of only axom terminating in this nucleus.
Recently, Mackay-Sim et al. ('83) have reported on the results of making small injections of HRP and WGA-HRP into the visual portion of the TRN of the rat.
They found sparse cell labelling in the deep, lateral MRF, in the PAG, and in the dorsal tegmental nucleus, but, curiously, not in the locus coeruleus (cf.
Kromer and Moore, '80) or raphe (cf.
Cropper et al., '84; Peschanski and Besson, '84).
It is also relevant to point out that Ahlsen and Lo ('82) have presented evidence for the existence, in the cat, of a projection from the MRF and raphe nuclei to the perigeniculate nucleus (PGN).

The latter nucleus is a thin sheet of cells and neuropil overlying the lateral geniculate nucleus intercalated between the latter and the TRN, and regarded by some authors as a specialized protion of the TRN with specifically visual system associations (e.g., Szentagothai, '72; Singer, '77).
Small injections of HRP into the PGN produced labelled cells in the deep MRF at the border between midbrain and pons (Ahlsen and Lo '82).
Our findings, however, are difficult to reconcile with these results, and indicate that there are few, if any, major direct projections from the brainstem reticular core to the TRN in the albino rat.
In only six out of 60 injections was convincing terminal label seen in the TRN, and such labelling was sparse.
One of these injections was into locus coeruleus (WGA-HRP) and produced sparse terminal label in the rostral TRN (see comments above).
The other five involved injections at the level of the superior colliculus, with injection tracks traversing the occipital cortex.

Since other injections at the same or similar rostrocaudal coordinates did not result in terminal labelling in the TRN we consider that the five positive cases are better explained either as the result of spread of HRP to the pretectal region and nucleus of the optic tract (Weber and Harting, '80; Holstege and Collewijn, '82), or as the result of leakage of HRP within the cerebral cortex with subsequent labelling of collaterals to the TRN of corticofugal axons (cf.
Jones, '75; Ohara and Lieberman, '79, '81), than as evidence for a projection to the TRN from this part of the midbrain.
The presence of labelled cell bodies in the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus in four of these five cases supports the latter interpretation.
This general conclusion is consistent with several other studies, notably those of Veazey and Severin ('801, Sotgiu et al. ('811, and Frassoni et al. ('84).
Sotgiu et al. ('81) found no cell labelling in any part of the BRF after injection of HRP into various regions of TRN in the cat.

Veazey and Severin ('80), working with rats, injected tritiated leucine into what they refer to as the deep mesencephalic nucleus, pars lateralis (equivalent to the lateral MRF in the present study and including the region of the MRF containing labelled cells in the study of Mackay-Sim et al. ('83)) and observed no terminal labelling within the TRN: furthermore, they also refer to a single experiment in which injection of HRP into the TRN was not followed by cell labelling in the deep mesencephalic nucleus.
Frassoni et al. ('84) found no anterograde labelling in the rat TRN after injection of HRP into the brainstem.
There are other degeneration and autoradiographic studies in the cat and rat that reinforce these negative findings (e.g., Chi, '70; Bowsher, '75).
The disagreements in the anatomical literature as to whether the TRN receives an input or inputs from the BRF, and if so from precisely where, are very considerable.

We believe that it is impossible to explain the discrepancies in terms of species differences, and difficult to reconcile them in terms of differences in the sites injected in the various anterograde and retrograde tracing experiments.

Although there is a natural tendency for positive findings to weigh more heavily than negative ones, the evidence for such projections rests most heavily on three studies: the autoradiographic study of anterogradely labelled terminals after injections of tritiated leucine in the cat MRF by Edwards and De Olmos ('76); the anterograde tracing study of Peschanski and Besson ('84) with WGA-HRP and the retrograde HRP (WGA-HRP) transport study of Mackay-Sim et al. ('83).

So far as the study of Edwards and De Olmos ('76) is concerned, (1) Jones ('81) has already drawn attention to the possibility that spread of injected label to the pretectal region-which projects to the TRN in the cat (Berman, '77bmight complicate interpretation of their findings, and (2) the 3H-leucine injections of Veazey and Severin ('80) and our HRP and WGA-HRP injections in the rat certainly included the region of the MRF corresponding to the nucleus cuneiformis.
Peschanski and Besson ('84) used 10% WGA-HRP in their injections of the raphe nuclei and the animals were allowed to survive for 48 hours.

The propensity for WGA-HRP to be transneuronally transported is now well documented, and given the high concentration of WGA-HRP and the long survival time used by Peschanski and Beson ( 84) it seems to us possible that at least some of the diffuse label found throughout much of the thalamus in their study may have been transneuronal in origin.
None of our four injections into the raphe medianus resulted in terminal or fibre labelling in TRN.

Why Mackay-Sim et al. ( 83) were able to label cells in the PAG, MRF, and dorsal tegmental nucleus while Veazey and Severin ( 80), Sotgiu et al. ( 811, we, and others have failed to find evidence for such projections is not clear.

Mackay-Sim et al. ( 83) consider but discount the possibility that the labelling they obtained might be due to spread of injectate beyond the confines of the visual TRN-for example, to the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus-for they found no labelling in the retina, optic tract, or brachium of the superior colliculus after such injections.

However, they do not adequately dispose of the question of possible labelling of damaged axons of passage in a region of the brain where such possibilities cannot be readily discounted, and it is relevant to point out that in similarly designed studies of the brainstem projections to the PGN in the cat, Ahlsen and Lo ( 82) were unable to be certain that the PGN could be injected without involvement of the superficial part of the subjacent lateral geniculate nucleus.

The existence of a body of experimental anatomical evidence for projections from the BRF to the TRN, supported by physiological evidence for effects on TRN neurons and on thalamocortical transmission of BRF stimulation (e.g., Singer, 77), reinforces the general uncertainty associated with negative findings in a study such as this.

Nevertheless, we believe that our findings merit serious consideration, not only because of some of the conflicts and weaknesses in the antecedent literature (reviewed above), but also in view of the facts that (1) we used sensitive tracing methods (HRP and WGA-HRP with TMB); (2) the injections were large, some were placed specifically in the regions thought to give rise to ascending derents to the TRN, and in total covered a large proportion of the BRF; and (3) the presence of terminal labelling in areas of the diencephalon other than the TRN codirmed that absence of label in the latter was unlikely to be due to general technical factors.
We are therefore led to conclude that, in the rat, direct ascending pathways from the BRF to the TRN are absent or at best extremely sparse.

We suggest that if the physiological effects on cortical activity of brainstem stimulation are mediated by the TRN rather than by direct routes to dorsal thalamic nuclei (Introduction) or to the cortex itself, then such effects must depend primarily upon indirect, polysynaptic pathways to the TRN.
